passages.text: Economics - EMEA/Euro Area/Europe

Based on the local French press (e.g., Les Echos), it seems likely that France's current government will fall on 8 September. We expect euro area HICP inflation to print unchanged at \(2.0\%\) y- o- y in August. UK price pressures are rising, according to survey data. Meanwhile, the Chancellor considers tax rises to meet fiscal rules, ahead of the Autumn Budget.

Based on the local French press (e.g., Les Echos), we believe the France's current government is likely to fall on 8 September. This would result in President Macron seeking another centrist caretaker government. We expect euro area HICP inflation to print unchanged at \(2.0\%\) y- o- y in August, with core price momentum for August 2025 broadly in line with typical August price momentum pre- pandemic. The recent monthly pace of net lending is marginally higher relative to pre- pandemic levels.

Recent indicators suggest rising price pressures in the UK, with the Lloyds Business Barometer showing rising price expectations and BRC data revealing increased food shop prices. On business activity, the Lloyds Business Barometer remains optimistic, reaching its highest level since 2015. Meanwhile, the government appears likely to implement tax rises in the Autumn Budget, with potential measures for consideration, reported in the press, being national insurance on rental income and new banking levies.
Headline euro area HICP inflation for August will be a key release. The final estimate of euro area Q2 GDP and Swedish and Swiss inflation will also be published.

We expect the euro area economy to recover only gradually in the near term, due to soft consumption and structural weakness. We believe US tariffs will be an important short- term headwind, whereas Germany and the EU's fiscal announcements will be material tailwinds only in the medium term. Following a more hawkish press conference at its July meeting, we think the ECB is now done cutting rates (terminal: \(2.00\%\) ).

The UK's growth outlook looks uncertain. Some surveys point to slow growth, others are stronger, and the official data have proved resilient. The job market is slowing. Monetary policy is likely limiting growth. While this suggests further modest monetary easing is needed, stick inflation and recovering growth could limit the extent of future cuts. We expect 25p cuts in November and February for a terminal rate of \(3.50\%\) .
Fig.1 France and UK have limited fiscal space
Source: IMF, Haver, Nomura
ECB: No further cuts. Terminal rate: \(2.00\%\) . (July review)
BoE: 25bp cuts at the next two MPR meetings (Nov 2025, Feb 2026). Terminal rate: \(3.50\%\) . (A ugust review)

France's PM Bayrou called a vote of confidence in his government in response to opposition of his fiscal reforms. The vote is scheduled for 8 September. As widely reported the extreme parties (France Insoumise, National Rally) have already stated that they would vote against Bayrou. We expect the centre- left Socialist Party will also vote against Bayrou, resulting in his government falling. President Macron would then likely seek another centrist caretaker government, tasked with undertaking similar fiscal reforms. Ultimately, there is the risk of snap elections should President Macron not succeed in finding a successor.

We expect euro area HICP inflation, released 2 September, is likely to print in line with the ECB's target of \(2.0\%\) . We track euro area HICP inflation at \(2.04\%\) . This is based on \(81\%\) of country- level data released thus far. Beyond August, we expect HICP inflation to hover around the ECB's \(2.0\%\) target until year- end. Country- level data so far suggest services and core goods price momentum in August 2025 were broadly in line with typical August price momentum pre- pandemic.

The ECB is well- placed to navigate upcoming US trade policy uncertainty, according to Mme Lagarde, as the depo rate at \(2.00\%\) is in the middle of the ECB's neutral range \(1.75 - 2.25\%\) . At the July meeting, Mme Lagarde suggested data misses or economic events would have to lower the ECB's 2027 HICP inflation forecast to alter the rate path.

Although Q2 2025 GDP growth was weaker than the ECB's forecast by 10bp, we believe Q3 2025 GDP growth will be stronger than the ECB's forecast by 30bp. In addition, we believe euro area HICP inflation is likely to average \(2.0\%\) in H2 2025. As a result, we do not expect further cuts from the ECB. We expect the ECB to leave its depo rate unchanged at \(2.00\%\) for the foreseeable future.

Net lending for July rose by €21.0bn (Figure 3), albeit this was slightly less than June's €25.3bn. Net lending in July was concentrated in mortgage lending (€11.9bn), followed by corporate lending (€7.6bn). Within corporate lending, the bulk was above 1y in duration, and in particular, the \(>5y\) bucket, which is typically indicative of longer- term investment plans rather than short- term cash flow management.

The ECB's latest Bank Lending Survey continues to suggest that there is pent- up demand for lending by households for mortgages. In particular, the Bank Lending Survey suggests the level of the interest rate is not weighing on consumer demand for mortgage lending (which is understandable as rates are neutral), albeit commercial banks remain cautious about lending due to the global macro backdrop and elevated economic uncertainty.

The recent pace of monthly net lending is marginally higher than the average during 2015- 19. However, the rolling 12m cumulative sum suggests we are some way from pre- pandemic levels of net lending (e.g., \(12\%\) less than in 2019, for total net lending).
Fig. 2: OAT-Bunds widened on France's political uncertainty
Fig. 3: Recent net lending is mostly mortgages
Source: ECB, Haver Analytics, Nomura

Following the government's failure to cut welfare spending this summer, and recent rises in bond yields, tax increases in the Autumn Budget seem likely to order for the Chancellor to meet her fiscal rules. However, in last year's general election, Labour promised not to raise income tax, national insurance or VAT. This week, potential tax hikes were discussed in UK media.

One potential tax rise reportedly being considered (source: The Times) is applying national insurance to rental income. However, critics of the suggestion say that this tax would likely raise rents by encouraging landlords to sell their properties. Another tax rise, suggested in a report by think tank the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR), could be a surcharge on banking profits or a new bank levy. Shares of many UK lenders slumped on Friday morning in response to the news.

The UK's tax take (taxes/GDP) is lower than many of its peer group countries. Hence, there is some scope to increase taxes. However, the argument against this is that the tax take is already due to rise to the highest level since the Second World War (Figure 4).

Indicators for prices are pointing to accelerating inflation. The prices balance in the Lloyds Business Barometer rose to its highest level since April in the August data (65, up from 61 in July). In addition, August BRC shop price data showed a \(0.9\%\) y- o- y rise, up from \(0.7\%\) in July. The m- o- m rate was broadly in line with the historic average for August, at \(0.2\%\) ; however, the food price index rose \(0.4\%\) m- o- m, well above the \(0.1\%\) August average for 2010- 2019.

Consumers may be adjusting spending in light of price rises. The CBI retail sales survey showed that the volume of retail sales compared with a year earlier indicator remained weak at - 32 in August, though was above - 34 in July. However, the sales volumes for the time of year balance deteriorated to - 19 in August from - 10 previously. Expectations for September did, however, improve.

The Lloyds Business Barometer remains the most optimistic survey for the UK and showed a continued strengthening in August, with the overall business confidence index climbing to its highest level since late 2015. This marked the fourth consecutive monthly rise, with the index reaching \(54\%\) after a two- point increase. The improvement was primarily driven by business activity expectations, which jumped five points to \(63\%\) a level not seen for more than 11 years.

Furthermore, this survey hasn't seen a hit from April's rise in employer national insurance contributions and the minimum wage, as staffing expectations continued their upward trend for the fourth straight month, reaching levels not seen in a decade.
Fig. 4: Spending cuts are difficult, and taxes are already high
Fig. 5: Lloyds business survey continues to be optimistic
Source: Lloyds, Macrobond, Nomura
Headline euro area HICP inflation for August will be a key release. The final estimate of euro area Q2 GDP and Swedish and Swiss inflation will also be published.

Sweden and Norway PMIs, August (Monday, Wednesday): In Sweden, the manufacturing PMI rose to a three- year high of 54.2 in July from 51.8 in June. However, this was offset by a fall in the services PMI, which returned to contractionary territory, hence the composite PMI was just inside expansion territory at 50.3 in July. We expect a rise in the composite index in August, in line with an improved Economic Tendency Survey. In Norway, the manufacturing PMI rose to 50.9 in July, after it had fluctuated around 50 for the past few months. We expect it to remain at a similar level in August.

UK Household borrowing, July (Monday): We forecast net mortgage lending of £3.0bn in July, down from June's strong £5.3bn, but still above the 2024 monthly average of £2.1bn. In addition, we expect mortgage approvals to fall to 63,500 from 64,200 in June. This is as some key activity indices in the July RICS survey weakened: the new buyer enquiries balance turned negative once again, falling to - 6 from 4 in June. The sales over the past month balance also fell to - 24 in July from - 1 in June. We expect £1.4bn of net consumer credit, in line with June and also the average for the past six months.

Euro area Unemployment rate, July (Monday): We forecast the euro area unemployment rate was unchanged at \(6.2\%\) in July, though we see material downside risks to \(6.1\%\) . Most euro area member states have seen their unemployment rates sidestep, and the decline in unemployment moderated markedly in Spain. However, Austria's unemployment rate fell by 10bp to \(7.3\%\) in July, and we see risks that Italy's unemployment rate, too, retraces in July after upward volatility in May and June.

Euro area HICP inflation, August (Tuesday): We believe underlying momentum in European inflation is slowing, and that euro area HICP inflation will hover around the ECB's \(2.0\%\) target until year- end. We will be looking out for two things in the August HICP inflation data: (1) is services price momentum slowing gradually in line with our expectations? And (2) is there any sign of weaker- than- normal core goods prices owing to Chinese goods dumping? We expect the answers to be yes and no, respectively. We forecast euro area HICP inflation will be unchanged at \(2.0\%\) y- o- y in August and core HICP inflation will ease to \(2.2\%\) .

Switzerland CPI inflation, August (Thursday): We expect CPI inflation of \(0.1\%\) y- o- y in August. This would be a 0.1pp slowdown from July's annual rate, as we expect weaker price pressures from the transport and hospitality sectors, which surprised to the upside in July. We also forecast core CPI inflation to slow to \(0.5\%\) y- o- y from \(0.8\%\) in July. The SNB forecasts CPI inflation to average \(0.1\%\) in Q3.

Sweden CPIF inflation, August (Thursday): We forecast Sweden CPIF inflation to rise to \(3.3\%\) y- o- y in August from \(3.0\%\) in July, and CPIF ex- energy to slow slightly to \(3.1\%\) , as we expect energy prices to continue to drive up the headline rate as household electricity bills have risen over the summer. In June and July, inflation surprised the Riksbank notably to the upside, partly driven by package holidays and car rental prices. Even with a partial unwinding of these price rises in August, we expect inflation to stand well above the Riksbank's forecast, which expects \(2.7\%\) inflation on both the CPIF and CPIF ex- energy measures.

UK Decision Maker Panel survey, August (Thursday): A notable point from the last survey is that realised annual employment fell by \(0.1\%\) in the three months to July, 0.4pp lower than in the three months to June, and expectations for employment growth over the next year have also weakened. Inflation expectations remained fairly sticky, as year- ahead CPI inflation expectations rose by \(0.1pp\) to \(3.2\%\) in the three months to July, though there was a decrease of \(0.1pp\) in the single month data. Annual own- price growth rose by \(0.1pp\) to \(3.6\%\) in the three months to July.

Euro area Retail sales, July (Thursday): We forecast euro area retail sales to have declined by \(1.0\%\) m- o- m in July. This forecast is based on \(31\%\) of country- level data already published and our assumptions for the remaining countries.
UK retail sales, July (Friday): We expect a small rise in retail sales volumes in July, of

0.4% m-o-m (excluding auto fuel). This would follow a 0.6% m-o-m rise in June and May's 2.9% drop. According to the BRC, annual UK retail sales (like-for-like) grew by 1.8% y-o-y in July, slower than June's 2.7% rise but above the average for the 12 months to June. In addition, sporting events including the Women's Euros could have boosted sales.
However, consumer confidence fell slightly in June and fairly high inflation likely dampened volumes growth.

**Germany Factory orders, July (Friday):** We expect Germany's factory orders fell by 1.4% m-o-m in July, following a 1.0% decline in June. This would be in line with surveys that suggested new orders fell on the month, from domestic and foreign firms.

**Euro area GDP, Q2 2025 – final estimate (Friday):** We forecast euro area GDP growth for Q2 2025 will be confirmed at 0.1% q-o-q in the final release. The expenditure breakdown, released alongside, is likely to suggest domestic demand contributed positively whereas net trade was a drag owing to the unwinding of tariff front-running that occurred in Q1 2025.
Fig. 6: Forecasts for European economic indicators released during the week beginning 1 September

Fig.7:Most recent ECBspeak

Rehn (28 August)Kazaks (24 August)ECB remains alert and ready to act on rates if needed.We are still in a good place. Not seeing big changes in economic outlook. Must ensure inflation remains around target. Market view &amp; very much in line with baseline.Lagarde (23, 25 August)Rehn (23 August)Inflation dropped sharply at low cost for employment. Europe's labour market in unexpectedly good shape. Europe's economy is resilient, not thriving. Tariffs may only have a small effect on GDP.Insurance cut' not needed with inflation at 2%. No reason to act before price, growth risks materialise. Inflation is "for now in a good place". Will retain full freedom of action at each meeting.Nagel (22 August)Lagarde (20 August)The bar for further cuts is high. Do not see many arguments for more easing. Inflation is not [of concern] anymore.Recent trade deals have alleviated, but certainly not eliminated, global uncertainty, which persists on account of the unpredictable policy environment.Nagel (12 August)Holzmann (6 August)We can react flexibly if necessary. Tariff uncertainty lower but not fully removed. Inflation no longer a major challenge. Interest rates are at a very good level.No reason to cut interest rates again.
Source:Bloomberg, Nomura
Fig.8:ECB dove-hawk spectrum
Fig.9:Most recent BoEspeak

Mann (26 August)Bailey (23 August)Inflation persistence is central case. Short, long-term household inflation expectations rising. Wage-setting is important source of elevated UK inflation. More persistent hold on rates appropriate.UK faces huge challenge to raise potential growth rate.Pill (8 August)Ramsden (7 August)Pace of future rate cuts more uncertain. Need to lean against second-round inflation effects. Approaching 2% to 4% neutral rate range. Little bit further to go on rates.Terminal rate estimates a broad range, no collective MPC view on terminal rate. QT impact on term premia up vs last estimate. Inflation persistence has surprised me.Lombardelli (7 August)Bailey (7 August)Food inflation higher than expected, food has salient role in inflation expectations.More uncertainty now about when steps are taken. Domestic factors main driver of rate-cut decision. Rates path is still downwards over time. Policy is still restrictive.
Source:Bloomberg, Nomura
